archetype_name: Family Weekend Advanced: South African Braai & Potjie
name: Apricot-Chutney Glazed Braai Pork Ribs with Tomato-Onion Smoor and Grilled Rolls
description: Low-and-slow oven ribs finished on the braai with a sticky apricot-chutney glaze, served with a grill-cooked tomato-onion smoor and charred bread rolls.
prep_steps: Line a large baking tray with foil.
Mix rib dry rub: 2 tsp braai spice mix, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp black pepper.
Pat pork ribs dry with paper towel and remove any tough membrane if still attached.
Whisk glaze: 1/2 cup BBQ sauce, 1/3 cup chutney, 2 tbsp apple cider vinegar, 1 tbsp brown sugar, 1/2 tsp chilli flakes, 1 tbsp olive oil.
Split bread rolls for grilling later.
cook_steps: Rub ribs all over with the dry rub.
Place ribs meat-side up on the foil-lined tray; cover tightly with another sheet of foil.
Bake at 150°C for 2 hours until tender but not falling apart.
While ribs bake, light the outdoor grill for medium-high, two-zone heat (direct and indirect).
Start the smoor on the grill: set a cast-iron pot over indirect heat, add 2 tbsp olive oil, then onions and a pinch of salt; cook, stirring, 8–10 min until softened.
Add garlic; cook 1 min. Add tomatoes and chopped apricot; season with 1/2 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp black pepper.
Simmer smoor uncovered over gentle grill heat, stirring occasionally, 25–35 min until thick; move pot closer to or away from heat to maintain a steady simmer. Adjust salt and black pepper.
Remove ribs from oven and discard foil. Brush a thin layer of glaze over both sides.
Transfer ribs to the grill, bone-side down over indirect heat. Close lid and cook 10 min.
Brush more glaze; move ribs briefly over direct heat to caramelize, 2–3 min per side, watching for flare-ups. Repeat glazing once more for a sticky finish.
Toast bread rolls cut-side down over direct heat 1–2 min until charred at the edges.
Rest ribs 5 min, then slice between bones. Serve with smoor and grilled rolls. Offer remaining glaze at the table.
instructions: Heat oven to 150°C.
Line a large baking tray with foil.
Peel and finely chop onions.
Roughly chop tomatoes.
Peel and finely chop garlic.
Roughly chop apricot.
Mix rib dry rub: 2 tsp braai spice mix, 1 tsp salt, 1 tsp black pepper.
Pat pork ribs dry with paper towel and remove any tough membrane if still attached.
Whisk glaze: 1/2 cup BBQ sauce, 1/3 cup chutney, 2 tbsp apple cider vinegar, 1 tbsp brown sugar, 1/2 tsp chilli flakes, 1 tbsp olive oil.
Split bread rolls for grilling later.
Rub ribs all over with the dry rub.
Place ribs meat-side up on the foil-lined tray; cover tightly with another sheet of foil.
Bake at 150°C for 2 hours until tender but not falling apart.
While ribs bake, light the outdoor grill for medium-high, two-zone heat (direct and indirect).
Start the smoor on the grill: set a cast-iron pot over indirect heat, add 2 tbsp olive oil, then onions and a pinch of salt; cook, stirring, 8–10 min until softened.
Add garlic; cook 1 min. Add tomatoes and chopped apricot; season with 1/2 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp black pepper.
Simmer smoor uncovered over gentle grill heat, stirring occasionally, 25–35 min until thick; move pot closer to or away from heat to maintain a steady simmer. Adjust salt and black pepper.
Remove ribs from oven and discard foil. Brush a thin layer of glaze over both sides.
Transfer ribs to the grill, bone-side down over indirect heat. Close lid and cook 10 min.
Brush more glaze; move ribs briefly over direct heat to caramelize, 2–3 min per side, watching for flare-ups. Repeat glazing once more for a sticky finish.
Toast bread rolls cut-side down over direct heat 1–2 min until charred at the edges.
Rest ribs 5 min, then slice between bones. Serve with smoor and grilled rolls. Offer remaining glaze at the table.
